Ok, I think you're seeing an error with this line?

```py3
if = 1 :
```

What value are you checking if it equals to 1? (Python requires you to check something, that's why it's a `SyntaxError`.) Also, remember to use the correct number of equals signs.

(Also: you can't have a variable name starting with a number, e.g. `1` or `1variable` because Python sees the `1` as a number.)

Right, so this is because your `if` line starts with a space.

Python uses indentation (spacing at the start of the line) to work out what's part of the `if`, and what's outside the block. Since the `if` line isn't part of any other "parent" `if`, it can't be indented.

File "program.py", line 3
    if input = 'left'  
    ^
IndentationError: unexpected indent

`KeyboardInterrupt` is the "error" you get when you stop the program using the keyboard. Often we do this by pressing Control-C ("C" for "Cancel"), but on Grok you can also press the stop button, which does the same thing. Don't worry - it's not a real error, and it doesn't mean anything is wrong.

By the way - you only need to have the line `from turtle import *` once, as long as it appears at the very top of your program, before any other code.

You have the first part right - you are asking for the direction and storing that in the variable called `msg`. The `input` function always gives you a string, so you do no really need to add the `str()` around the `input` but it won?€?t do any harm.

No worries, we're here to help! :)

The problem is with the 3rd line of your code, 

```py3
from turtle import *
arrow =int(input('Which way? '))
  if arrow = left
  forward (100)
  left (120)
```
See how your `if` statement is indented a few spaces in. This is causing python to get confused. The `if` statement should start with no space before it, just like the line above it. 

Then, everything that you want inside the `if` statement (such as the forward and left commands), should be indented inside it.

If you want a reminder, have a look at some of your solutions to the previous problems (such as Backetball Bunny), for an example of how to correctly indent an `if` statement.

Good luck!

Hi Andre,

Are you seeing a `SyntaxError` on line 11 (`else  pol == 'right':`)?

This is happening because `else` blocks can't have a condition. With `if`, you check a condition, and you can do the same with `elif`, but `else` is for *everything else* and so it's not allowed to have a condition.

help

I also noticed your use of ``int`` and ``str``. 
These function are used when you are changing from text to numbers (or from numbers to text)

When you ask ``Which way?``, Python will give you an error because the answer (*right* or *left*) can't be changed to a number. 

On a different note, ``str(d)`` doesn't change anything because ``d`` is already text. Good luck!
Or you can also use tabs instead of spaces

Hi Dean,
Python cares a lot about spacing. All the code under the ``if`` statement needs to be shifted *4 spaces* to the right, so Python understands that you want to run the code if the condition is true.

from turtle import *
d = int(input('which way? '))
if str(d) == 'right':
right(90)
right(120)
forward(100)
right(120)
forward(100)

if str(d) == 'left':
left(90)
left(120)
forward(100)
left(120)
forward(100)

Hey Eloise! So the code I gave you was only an example, you won't need to `print` anything for this question. You're going to need to think about which bits of code you want to run `if` the input is `'left'`, and which bits to run otherwise.

Remember that any lines that are indented after your `if` or `else` will be what is run according to the `if` statement. For example:
```
if name == 'left':
  # Do something that should happen if name is equal to 'left'.
  # Do something else.
else:
  # Do something that should happen if name is equal to 'right'.
  # Do something else.
```

Hope that clarifies things a bit :).

Hi Eloise! It looks like you've done an awesome job so far, your left and right arrows look perfect :). So the way `if` statements work is that anything within the  `if` bit (the `if` *block*) only runs when the condition you provide is `True`.

For example, let's say I want to make a program that tells me whether I've inputted `'left'` or `'right'`. That would look something like:

```
direction = input('Left or right? ')
if direction == 'left':
  print('You chose left!')
else:
  print('You chose right!')
```

Notice how the `print('You chose left!')` only runs *if* we enter `'left'`. Anything inside that `if` block (that is, anything after the `if` condition that is indented) will also only be run if the condition we give it is `True`.

If that's not entirely clear, there are some (really awesome!) [notes on how to make decisions in Python](https://groklearning.com/learn/challenge-beginners-2018/w2p1/0/) that I think would be very helpful to read as many times as you like!

Hi Daniel,

First of all, don't worry about pasting your code into your messages: the tutors can see it already. :)

This is a tricky bug! The problem is on this line:
```
if angle == left:
```
which is doing something very unobvious: it's comparing `angle` with the `left()` function which turns the turtle!

Since the `angle` variable doesn't contain the *function*, but instead the *string* `'left'`, it's not equal, and so the code inside the block doesn't run.

Hi Arjun.

Take another look at [this page](https://groklearning.com/view-submissions/41208047/challenge-beginners-2018/w1p2/11/) of the notes. In there, it explains how `forward()` is used to move the turtle forwards, but `left()` and `right()` make the turtle turn on the spot.

Think of it like driving a car. You can't make it magically move to the left or right. Instead you need to first turn it so the car is facing the direction you want to move, and then press the accelerator to go forwards.

So, instead of starting with `right(30)`, because the turtle is already facing in the correct direction, you can start with `forward(30)`. 

I hope that helps! :D

Remember, indentation is really important. It tells python which block your code is part of. Let's take a closer look at your code

```
  for count in range (4):
    forward (100)
    left (90)
    end_fill ()
```
What's happening here is that python will go forward 100 steps, turn left 90 and then end the fill. It will do this 4 times. Once we close the fill, it's closed and we'll need to make a new one. But we don't want to close it straight after drawing one side of the diamond.

Let's unindent it so that it sits in the `if` block. We want it outside of the `for` loop because we want to close the fill after we draw the diamond.

Hi Vernica,

Each time you call `draw_blade` (line 14), fade is always the same value, **255/num_blades**. 

For example if the number of blades is 8:
* For the first fan blade, the fade value should be zero.
* For the second fan blade the fade value should be 31.875 (255/num_blades)
* For the third fan blade the fade value should be 63.75
...
* For the last blade, the fade value should be 255

Also, you don't need this line:
```
fillcolor(0, 255/num_blades, 0)
```

So for each value of the loop, we want to update the value of `fade` to be more and more faded. So, perhaps to set up an example:

```py3
# Start off with a fade of 0
fade = 0
# Loop 8 times
for i in range(8):
  # Print out what we are currently up to
  print("My current fade is: " + str(fade))
  # Then add 255/8 to fade each time
  fade = fade + 255/8
```

If you run this code, you get something pretty close to what you want. Start off with a fade value of 0, then each time we go through the loop, we update fade so that it gets bigger and bigger by the correct amount each time.

So, you're really close.

Let's say you call `draw_fan(8)`. This will draw a fan with 8 blades, by calling `draw_blade` 8 times with the loop on line 21.

Let's figure out what those calls will look like. We calculate fade on line 22, which will be:
```
fade = 255/num_blades = 255/8 = 31.875
```

Then, we call `draw_blade` with this value.
```
draw_blade(fade) = draw_blade(31.875)
```
We do this 8 times in the loop on line 21.

But we actually want this value to change. 
 - The first blade should have a fade value of `0*31.875 = 0`
 - The second `1*31.875 = 31.875`
 - The third `2*31.875 = 63.75`

Can you change your code on lines 22/23 so that the value changes each time?

Hi Ethan. You've got two main issues with your code. 

1 is your math operation for modifying your `fade` variable. You need to add the colour values that correspond to how many blades you're drawing - so 255 divided by the number of blades. 

2 is the order in which you're setting and modifying your `fade` variable. Programs need us to be _very_ strict with how we do that. from turtle import *

def draw_blade(fade):
  # Draw a faded blue fan blade.
  fillcolor(fade, fade, 255)
  begin_fill()
  forward(100)
  left(90)
  forward(20)
  goto(0,0)
  end_fill()
  
def draw_fan(num_blades):
  fade = 0
  for i in range(num_blades):
    draw_blade(fade)
    fade = 225 / num_blades
    left(20)
    right(90)
          
    
                
  

if __name__ == "__main__":
  draw_fan(2)

Hi Jared,

Since the NCSS Challenge is now over, we won't be providing any more tutoring support, and you can now read the solutions yourself. There are two things you needed to do to finish this question:

1. Add `end_fill()` to the end of the `draw_blade` function, like this:

```
def draw_blade(fade):
  # Draw a faded blue fan blade.
  red = fade
  green = fade
  blue = 255
  fillcolor(red, green, blue)
  begin_fill()
  forward(100)
  left(90)
  forward(20)
  goto(0, 0)
  right(90)
  end_fill()
```

2. Fix a typo on this line:

```
    draw_blade(1*255/num_blades)
```

I think you meant `i` instead of `1`. Multiplying by `i` means you'll draw with a different fade each step through the loop, because `i` will have a different value at each step through the loop.

Hi Tayla, certainly. :) 
Let's take a look at the error you are getting:
```
ValueError: red component of colour must be in the range [0, 255] (not 2040)
```

When we set colours, we need to remember that they are between 0 and 255. This error is saying that we tried to set one of the colours to 2040 which is outside the range.

If we take a look at your program, we can see that this is happening because of your draw_fan function:
```
def draw_fan(num_blades):
  # Call the draw_blade function to draw a fan 
  fade = 255*num_blades
  draw_blade(fade)
```

Notice how you're multiplying the `num_blades` by 255? This results in the fade being larger than 255 sometimes and is why we get this error.

Remember, the problem description says that the fade between each blade is calculated by *dividing*: `255 / num_blades`.

def draw_rect(width, height, colour):

    left(90)

    left(90)
    forward(width)
    left(90)
    forward(height)
    left(90)

Hi Emily! The error says `IndentationError: expected an indented block`. Python is saying that it's confused, because on the previous line of code (`for i in range(number):`), you ended the line with a colon `:`, and after a colon Python always expects the next line (or next lines) to be indented.

By indenting the lines, you tell Python to include them in the `if` block. When the `if` block's condition is true, the indented lines will be run.

Can you figure out which lines you need to indent (thus including them in the `if` block)?

You need to be careful with the indentation for the if. All the lines of code that you want to run inside the if needs to have the same amount of space at the front. For example:

```py3
size = 10
if size < 5:
  print('A')
  print('B')
print('C')
if size < 8:
  print('D')
```
Can you see how this will only print C?

Hi Pia
Great work figuring out the tree shapes. 

One thing to watch when you use 'if' is how you let the computer know which lines of code to run if the condition is true, for example if question does equal Summer.

Have you heard if indenting? It's when you move your lines of code to the right by two spaces (or a tab) - this lets the computer know it's code only to run when the 'if' statement is true. 

So:

if question == "Summer"
    from turtle import *
    pensize(10)

etc.
When your code goes right back to the left hand side, it tells your computer to run the code in all cases, not just when the 'if' statement is true.

Good luck!

Hi Paige! This is a *really* awesome attempt so far - your summer tree works almost perfectly! The thing I can see that might be confusing you right now is choosing what parts of your code you want to run *conditionally*. What you're doing right now is:
```
if season == 'summer':
 pencolor('green')
pensize(10)
forward(50)
# ...
```

What this does is it checks `if season == 'summer'`, and then runs `pencolor('green')` *only if* that's `True`. However, no matter what, your program will *always* run
```
pensize(10)
forward(50)
# ...
```
because of the way you've indented those lines. To specify what lines you want to be part of an `if` *block*, you'll need to indent (typically using two spaces) the lines that you want to only run `if` some condition is `True`. So you might instead want to do:

```
if season == 'summer':
  pencolor('green')
  pensize(10)
  forward(50)
  # ...
```

Also, try thinking about the order in which you want your program to do things. Maybe you'd want your trunk-drawing code to run at the end, because it's the last thing that happens.

Good luck! :)

Python is picky with spaces :)

Everything you want to run, if the `command == "Summer"` has to be shifted to the right by 4 spaces.

For example:
```
if command == "Summer":
  from turtle import *

pencolor("green")
pensize(10)
forward(50)
```

To this:
```
if command == "Summer":
    pencolor("green")
    pensize(10)
    forward(50)
```

Try that out and see how it goes :)

Also, you only need `from turtle import *` line once, right at the top

Hey Mridula, I think you might want your line 26 to be indented differently. Remember that in Python, the `if` block (the bit of code to be run `if` the condition is `True`) is indented so that it's to the right of the `if` (usually two spaces). For example,
```
if season == 'Autumn':
  pencolor('orangered')
  pensize(10)
  # ...
```
would be valid.

In your case, you're doing:
```
if season == 'Autumn': 
pencolor('orangered')
```
which Python doesn't like, because it's expecting a *block* (something indented) after the `if` condition.

Hope that helps! :)

def draw_swatch(x, y, colour):

Yes

You've added quote marks around the function call so it isn't being actioned. 

```"draw_swatch(20, 10, 'violet')"```

should instead be:

```draw_swatch(20, 10, 'violet')```

The part that needs to be a string (`'violet'`) is already created as one with the quote marks around it and is then assigned to the variable `colour` because it is the third argument in the call and `colour` is the third item in the function definitely (`def draw_swatch(x, y, colour):`)

Make sense?
it still doesn't seem to be working

You are super close! Computers are a little annoying though and use American spelling a lot. For example, you should be using `fillcolor(colour)` rather than `fill_colour('colour')`. The first thing is to remove the underscore (the turtle doesn't use this for colours) and the U in colour so it is spelt the American way: color.

The second thing is you want to pass in the variable from your call (`draw_swatch(20, 10, 'violet')`). If you add '' marks around it Python will try and read it as a string instead of replacing it with the contents of the variable.

Give it a try now.

Hi Kieren,

In a `for` loop, we need a sequence of things to loop over. For example, we can [loop over a string](https://groklearning.com/learn/challenge-beginners-2018/w3p2/1/) because a string is just a sequence of characters (like letters, numerals, punctuation, or emoji). So a `for` loop on a string just says "do this for each character in the string".

If we want to repeat something a specific number of times (say, 5 times), then we need a sequence which has 5 things in it. We could do this using strings, if we had a word of the right length:

```python
for i in 'apple':
  print('This sentence is repeated 5 times.')
```

But we shouldn't need to have a word of the right length just because we want to do something 5 times. The `range` function gives us sequence with the right number of things in it. If we wanted to do something 5 times, we can put it in a `range(5)` loop:

```python
for i in range(5):
  print('This sentence is repeated 5 times.')
```

And because the number that `range` takes can be a variable, we can ask the user how many times to loop (like you've done with `a` in this question).

That's the really simple answer: doing a `for` loop on `range(x)` will repeat the same thing `x` times.

Where `range` is also useful is that the sequence it uses will give you each number from 0 up to one less than your input number. So we can use this to count things, not just repeat the same thing over and over:

```python
for i in range(5):
  print('The next number is', i)
```

The variable `i` is used to hold the current value we're up to in the sequence. It doesn't have to be called `i`, we can rename it like this:

```python
for a in range(5):
  print('The next number is', a)
```

The slides [from here](https://groklearning.com/learn/challenge-beginners-2018/w3p2/4/) show you how to use range for counting from a different starting point, or counting backwards, and so on.

In short, we can use `range` to either:

* repeat the same thing a specific number of times (like we did in this question), or
* count between two numbers (like we did in the Lift Off question)

Hi Brae, I can see you've almost solved this one! :) The shape is perfect, you're just missing the calls to `pencolor()` and `pensize()`.

Here's a hint: To set the pencolor of the turtle, you need to call the `pencolor` function like this:

`pencolor("blue")`

Or perhaps: `pencolor("red")`

`pencolor("green")`

And to set the pensize, you need to call the `pensize` function like this: 

`pensize(5)`

Or perhaps: `pensize(3)`

It is a bit tricky to see these things from the marker examples ?€? I might not have known what the problem was if I didn't know how setting the pen colour and thickness works.

The way you can think about it is that the turtle begins with a default colour and thickness, and will use that for drawing all the lines until you tell it otherwise. For example, you could draw lines in red, and then change it to blue:

```py3
from turtle import *

forward(100)
left(120)

pencolor('red')
pensize(2)

forward(100)
left(120)

pencolor('blue')
pensize(3)

forward(100)
```

Hi Kaitlin,

You are very nearly there. Your drawing code inside the loop is exactly right.
The problem is in setting up the loop.

You ask the user for the number of steps and then put that number in the `steps` variable - so far, so good.
But have a closer look at what your `for` loop is doing. Right now, you are telling it to loop from 1 up to `steps` decreasing the count by 1 each time.

Go back and have a look at the example in [Repeating shapes](https://groklearning.com/view-submissions/40668784/challenge-beginners-2018/w3p2/10/) so you can see how to use a simpler form of the `range` function that will do what you want.

Hi Angus,

Every bracket ( needs to have a corresponding close bracket ). Check your first line again to ensure that the brackets are closed properly. The input has a set of brackets ("...") and because you have an int around that, the whole set needs to be enclosed in brackets. Another way to check is the number of (( and )) you have in a line of code - they need to be equal.

Next, try to draw one step. Once you get that working, the next part becomes a little clearer. You don't know how many steps you will draw (but you do know that it's the same set of instructions to draw a step that will be repeated). Can you think of anything you have learnt so far that will help you repeat a set of steps?

`pass` is used when something is required but you have not completed it yet. Essentially it does nothing. To see why it is used, suppose you've started a function
```
def draw_line(redness, height):

if __name__ == '__main__':
  draw_line(200, 30)
```

This will not run since it'll expect something after the `draw_line()` function. However we can add a `pass` so it does run. Basically `pass` is just something we use when we want to run a program that we haven't entirely completed.

Hi Evie,

You're so close on this one! There's just one line that is in the wrong spot which is causing the marker to see tiny little differences. It's not really something you can spot easily, so I'm going to tell you which line it is.

The problem is where you have this line:
```
  bgcolor('#444444')
```
You have it in the `draw_line` function, which means that every time you draw a line, it resets the background.

What's a better place to put that background? We really only want the background to be drawn once, so you could put it under this line:
```
if __name__ == '__main__':
```

Or under the line:
```
def draw_elevator():
```

That way, the background will only get drawn once.

Nice work!

Hi Joseph,

You have written the `draw_line` function but you never call it. You are drawing the 6 lines manually in the `main` section.

The idea behind using a function like `draw_line` is that it allows you to repeat tasks more easily and it means that if you have a problem in your drawing code, you only have to fix it in one place instead of in 6 places.

In your `draw_line` function, you are using the `height` correctly.

  draw_line(0, 0, 0, 30)
  penup()
  backward(50)
  left(90)
  forward(20)

  draw_line(40, 0, 0, 30)
```

def draw_line(redness, height):

  # Write your code here

 pencolor(redness,0,0)

 penup()

 goto(-50,height)

 pendown()

 forward(100)

 reset()

 bgcolor('#444444')

 redness= 0

 height= 0

 penup()

 goto(-50,height)

 pendown()

 pensize(10)

 for i in range(5):

 pencolor(redness,0,0)
 forward(100)
    
 pass

If you look at the at the result of the marking, notice that you get an error when testing a black line with y-coordinate of 0 (i.e. when running `draw_line(0,0)`).  When I modified your code to call `draw_line(0,0)`, this is the error that I get:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "program.py", line 33, in <module>
    draw_line(0,0)
  File "program.py", line 7, in draw_line
    pencolor(R)
  File "/opt/grok/python3/turtle.py", line 2032, in pencolor
    return WORLD.api_pencolor(check_color(*color))
  File "/opt/grok/python3/turtle.py", line 1595, in check_color
    raise TypeError('Expected an RGB triple or string color name')
TypeError: Expected an RGB triple or string color name
```

If you look at the error message, notice that the `TypeError` is caused by the call of `pencolor` inside the `draw_line` function and the reason for this is because the value of `R` is not in the correct type (i.e. format). Don't forget that the `redness` argument of the `draw_line` function is the value for the red channel of the pen.

Hope this helps!

Your code is looking interesting but you aren't using your function. A function is something that you build once but use over and over again, given different arguments.

I hope that makes sense and helps. You can still use your while loop in 'main' to call the function with the different height and redness variables if you want, but only **after** ```draw_line(redness, height)``` is doing what it needs to.

Hey Michael,

For your height you are currently staying in the same place, notice how you are calling for `h` (`height`) in the line below but never changing the value of `h`? This is causing your line to draw in the same place over and over again.

```goto(-50, h)```

For your redness you need to consider the order of operations that Python is going to perform for you. The last thing you do is:

```x += 40```

and then the program loops back around. One of the first things you then do is set `x = 0`, wiping away your previous change. When you are doing something like this you need to declare the variable outside of the loop so that it isn't reset every time the loop runs.

For example if we arranged it like this we would have `x = 0` when the function is first called and then each loop would increase it by the set amount.

```
def draw_line(redness, height):
  x = 0
  for i in range(6):
    bgcolor('#444444')
    [... other code ...]
    x += 40
```

Hi Natasha,

The value needs to be given when you call the function - [just like these notes](https://groklearning.com/learn/challenge-beginners-2018/w5p1/13/), your function takes 2 arguments, so you need to provide 2 values when you call the function.

For example:

```py3
def add(a, b):
  return a+b

# This works
print(add(3, 4))
x = 5
y = 6
print(add(x, y))

# Error: Need 2 arguments, but only gave 1
print(add(3))
```

Hi, sorry for the wait. If you look closely at your turtle while it's moving, notice how it turns right a bit before it turns left? To draw a single polygon, you need to move forward by 30 steps then move left by `angle`, then repeat. You only have to turn right once you've finished drawing the *whole* polygon. If you turn right in the middle of drawing the polygon, you'll end up moving in the wrong direction. It just so happens that for 3, it means you move straight and for 6 it means you draw the polygon upside down.

Hi Jake,

When I run your code, I get an `IndentationError` - that means that the indenting (the spaces at the beginning of the line) aren't quite right, and the computer doesn't understand what it's meant to do.

Remember that all `for` loops need to have the thing that you want it to do _indented_ in. 

I think in this case though, that you probably want line 10 (`  for s in range(sides):`) and line 14 (`  for s in range(sides):`) un-indented, so you remove the spaces so it's right at the beginning of the line. Otherwise it would happen too many times.

Hi Alexander,

The problem is caused because there are two `if` statements.

Let's say that `y='_'`.

If the first `if` is executed, then `a=a+1` and `x=x-1`.

Then, the second `if` statement is evaluated, but `y[a]` won't work because `a` now equals 1 and `y[1]` doesn't exist.

You can fix it by using an `elif` in place of the second `if`. This means that it will only get tried if the first `if` was False.

Hey Ashley! Your code is almost perfect! There are just 2 things you need to be aware of.

1. Using a single = symbol tells Python to store something in the variable. When you use 2 of them, ==, it tells Python to check if the first thing is the same as the second thing. Because they can be confusing Python also understand `is` which is my preference. So you could use `if character is '_':` for example.

2. Pay attention to whether you want a `0` or an `o`. They look very similar but the computer is never confused by that!

This line:

for letter in msg:

```

Hi Mohamed.

Let's look at this bit of your code

```
x = 7
if x < 7:
  print('New world record!')
else: 
  print('No record yet. Keep training!')
```

Notice how you create a variable called `x`, and make it equal to 7. The next line you ask, *"Is x less than 7?"*. But you just set it so that x is always equal to 7. So that `if` statement will always be false, and you'll always print `'No record yet. Keep training!'`.

You need to make sure that you use the value from the user's `input` in your `if` statement instead.

Yep!

At the moment, your `for` loop is going through these steps for each character in the string:

1. Check if the character is a letter (`if c.isalpha()`)
2. If it is, shift it to the next letter, and store the new letter in the `character` variable
3. Add this new `character` to the output string

The `character` variable only gets updated when `c` is a letter. If you test your code with `"aa bb"` as input, you'll get `bbbcc` as output.

Because the space isn't a part of the alphabet, your program skips the `if` code and adds whatever is in the `character` variable to the output string.

Thanks for the help! I did it! I think the way I solved it was a bit difficult. I did it so that the only thing that would be shifted would be the Captial letters and I did this by working out what the number code for 'A' and 'Z' are. Here is my code if you want to see: 
code = input('Secret message: ')
store = ""
minCode= 65 # for A
maxCode= 90 # for Z
for character in code:
   if ord(character) >= minCode:
      if ord(character) <= maxCode:
        shiftedNumber = ord(character)+1
        shiftedCharacter = chr(shiftedNumber)
        store = store + shiftedCharacter
      else: store = store + character
   else: store = store + character
    
print(store)

Hi Gabriella.

To solve this question, you can't have a `print` statement inside your `for` loop. Instead, you'll need to use another string variable to build up the final answer one character at a time. 

Then, once the `for` loop is finished, you can print out the final answer string.

Have  a look at these two examples (try running them) to see if you can see the difference

```py3
my_word = "hello"
for letter in my_word:
  print(letter)
```

vs.

```py3
my_word = "hello"
answer = ""
for letter in my_word:
  answer = answer + letter
print(answer)
```

You can choose to either do the `output` thing _OR_ use `end=''`. Just pick one.

You will also need this at the start of the program to define `output`:

```py3
output = ''
```
Just make sure that `print(output)` is at the _very end_ of the program, with no spaces before it (no indent). This will make it run _after_ the `for` loop.

An alternative method is to store the characters in a string:

```py3
output = output + next_character
```

Then at the end you can use `print(output)` to show the message.

Hi Emma,

This command:

```py3
range(int(msg)):
``

Is saying: "Create me a range of numbers, starting at 1 and ending with the number contained in `msg`."

However, `msg` contains words, not numbers.

Instead, you can use:

```py3
for i in msg:
```

This will take one letter at a time and put it into `i`, for each execution of the `for` loop.

Hi Jaxon! Remember that `ord` works by taking in a *character* and outputs a number - for example, `ord('a')` is `97`. Since you can only use `ord` on a single character at a time, you might want to grab a single character in the message at at time. Can you think of what you might need to use to grab *each* letter in the message?

Also, you'll definitely want to treat the message as a string, not an integer. I'd suggest using the variable name `message` rather than `a`. Python doesn't actually care what variable names you use, but it'll make it a lot less confusing to *you* when you try to figure out what your program is doing.

Good luck! :)

Hi Renesa! You're actually really close! Right now you're getting:
```terminal
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "program.py", line 4, in <module>
    message = ord(message[i])
TypeError: 'int' object is not subscriptable
```

This is because the first time your `for` loop runs, you're actually overwriting the `message` string, and turning it into `ord(message[i])`, which is an integer. Then, the next time the loop runs, it tries to run `message = ord(message[i])`, but it can't do `message[i]` because `message` is an integer, not a string!

Can you think of a way to fix this so that you don't lose `message`, the original string?

P.S. We want to print each `next_character`, but all in the same line. If you try to `print(next_character)` inside the `for` loop, you'll notice that it prints them all on a new line, which isn't what we want. I think if you read the problem notes carefully, you'll figure out the way to `print` it out the way we want it to!

Good luck :)

For example:
```py3

This line:

```
for code in msg:
```

takes one character at a time from `msg` and puts it into `code`.

This line:

```
 if code.isupper():
```

then checks whether or not `code` contains an Uppercase letter. If it does, then the `if` section is run. If not, the `else` section is run.

In the `else` section, this line:

```
output = output + code
```

takes the `code` (which was set by the `for` statement) and simply adds it to output.

For example, this program would print the original message:

```
output=''
message = input('Message?')
for code in message:
  output = output + code
print(output)
```

This line:

clears the content of `output`. It should be placed at the _very beginning_ of the program. At the moment, it is inside the `for` loop, which means it loses its content after every letter.

Also, this line:

```

```

is currently indented (with a space before it), so it is running _inside_ the `for` loop. To make it run _after_ the `for` loop, remove the indent (remove the spaces before it).

Hi Dean, you have a great start. The reason why you get **IndexError: string index out of range** at the end is because `len(d)` starts counting from 1 but `d[]` starts counting from 0.

For example, if `d = "THE IDES OF MARCH"`:
* The first letter of the sentence, "T", will be `d[0]`
* The last letter of the sentence, "H", will be `d[16]`
*  `len(d)` is 17

For any characters that are not in the alphabet, your program will need to print the **same** character. For example, a space should be a space, a question mark should be a question mark. So, you will need an `if` statement to determine whether or not to change the character.

To make them print on one line, you have a couple of choices:

You could store the characters in a variable and then just print the variable at the end, like this:

```py3
output += next_character
```

And at the end, just print `next_character`.

Or, you can print one character at a time without a new line:

```py3 
print (next_character, end='')
```

However, this might need an empty `print()` at the end to finish the line for the marking system.

Hi Alex,

The `print()` statement always adds a 'new line' at the end.

One way is avoid this is to store the characters in a variable instead of printing them:

```py3
output += next_character
```

Then, use `print(output)` at the end of the program.

Or, you could use:

```py3
print(next_character, end='')
```

This does not print the new line after each character. However, you might need to print an extra `print()` at the end of the program to make the marking system happy.

This line:

```py3

is not doing what you expect it to do. It is creating a list (known as a _tuple_) .

```py3
  nxt_char = nxt_char.replace('!', ' ')
  nxt_char = nxt_char.replace('@', '?')
  nxt_char = nxt_char.replace('-', ',')
  print(nxt_char, end='')

Hi Toby,

Python has very strict rules for writing `for` loops and `if` statements.

Each line that starts with `for` , `if`, `else` and other similar keywords must end with a colon :

And the lines after that that are inside the loop or inside the if, they must be indented. In this case, you have an `if` inside a `for` so the lines that are inside the `if` need to be indented twice.

Hey Hunter. You're on the right track, you've just messed up your variables a little. When we use `for letter in line` like you have, the `letter` variable becomes each individual letter in the string `line`. This means when we want to modify the letter, we should call that variable (letter), not the whole string (line). 

You'll also need to look at the `ord()` function. simply saying `letter + 1` won't really do anything because `letter` is a string of 1 character, so adding strings and integers won't work. `ord() will help you find out what number in the alphabet your character is, then you can modify it with addition.

You can replace this:

```py3
code = ord(x[b])

with this:

code = ord(i)

Another tip is that you might want to use more descriptive variable names, such as:

```py3
message = input(...)
for character in message:
```

This makes it easier to read your own code and understand what it is doing.

Hi Vanessa,

To solve this question, you can't have a `print` statement inside your `for` loop. Instead, you'll need to use another string variable to build up the final answer one character at a time. 

Then, once the `for` loop is finished, you can print out the final answer string.

Have  a look at these two examples (try running them) to see if you can see the difference

```py3
my_word = "hello"
for letter in my_word:
  print(letter)
```

vs.

```py3
my_word = "hello"
answer = ""
for letter in my_word:
  answer = answer + letter
print(answer)
```

name = input('Enter your name? ')
for character in name:
  print(character)
The for loop runs the indented code for each element in a sequence, in this case each character in the name string entered by the user.

If there are three letters in the name, then the for loop will run print(character) three times, once for each character.

On the first run through (the first iteration) the character variable will be the first letter from name, on the second iteration the character variable will change to the second letter, on the third time it will be the third letter and so on.

So for the loop above (if the user enters Bob), the value stored in character will first be 'B' on the first run through, then it will be repeated with 'o', and finally 'b'.

Hi Nikki,

Let's take a look at your program. Python uses *indentation* (spacing) to work out what's part of a loop (or conditional [`if`] statement), and what's not.

If you look closely, you'll see that your `else` isn't indented, so it's not part of the loop - this means that the `else` will only run once at the end of the `for` loop.

Since spaces will be `False` for the `if character.isupper():`, it would check for an `else`, but the `else` isn't part of the loop, so it just goes to the next character.

Hope this helps! Let us know if you have any more questions. :)

As for printing one line, there are two options...

One option is to store the letters in a variable:

```py3
print(next_character, end='')

```

1. Test whether each character is something you _don't_ want to encrypt. Encrypt everything else
2. Test each character and **only encrypt** the ones that are uppercase letters. Leave other characters the same

Option 2 is the easier option here (it's easier to check for an uppercase letter than for any punctuation/space character).

msg = 'hello world'

prints:

because the first string in the brackets is the string that will get replaced if found, and the second string is what the first string will be replaced with.

The tricky parts of this problem are the numbers and words. Your first line is excellent, so don't change that!

You've used `int` in your first line, which tells the computer straight away that **a** is a number. The computer will remember this, so you don't need to use `int` anywhere else in your program when talking about **a**.

When you type stuff inside apostrophes (like `'hello'`, or `'100'`) the computer will treat everything inside them as words (or *strings*).

This means that if you have a number in green, like `'100'`, the computer won't know that it's supposed to be a number, so it won't be able to do maths on it.

Can you see if there are any numbers in your code which the computer might be treating as words?

Hi Zoe,

Although us humans see 123 and 123 as the same thing, computers are not as clever and need much more detail. "123" is treated as a string (almost like a series of alphabet letters) and 123  (without the quotation marks) is treated as a number. 

So, although you have the right logic in line 1, the input has to be treated as a number (integer), because we want to do arithmetic calculations with it.

To get an input as a number, you need to do something like this:
a = int(input('Enter a number: '))

Word = input('Word? ')
print(Word + Word + Word)
```

Just popping in to mention that `print(count + ' t crossed')` **is** a bit different to `print(count, ' t crossed')`:

- `+` won't concatenate an `int` with a `str`, but `,` will.
- `+` doesn't add a space, but `,` will.

Hey Philip!
Just wanted to mention that `print(count + ' t crossed')` is a bit different to `print(count, ' t crossed')`:

- `+` won't concatenate an `int` with a `str`, but `,` will.
- `+` doesn't add a space, but `,` will.

Also make sure that you convert the variable to a string, before you add any strings together. This line:

```
 print(str(TEE + " t's crossed.")) 
```

Should be:
```
 print(str(TEE) + " t's crossed.") 
```

Hi Emma.

The problem you have here is that because you use `elif`, you only ever get the count of one of the letters. As soon as one of your `if` or `elif` statements triggers, none of the others will.

However, for this question, you don't actually heed to use `if` or `elif` at all. This is because `count()` will work even if the letter isn't in the line.

You should just be able to do this:

```
line_1 = line.count('i')
line_4 = line.count('t')
line_3 = line.count('T')
```

To include an apostrophe in your text, you can do it one of two ways:

```py3
print("I'm using double quotes")
print("I\'m using a backslash")
```

Usually, we use the one with double quotes because it's easier to read. (Backslashes have some fancy meanings in programming, and one of them means "don't end the string".)

For counting both the lowercase and capital `t`'s, you can either count them individually (and add them up), or you can make the input lowercase to count them all at once (but count the lowercase `i`'s first).

Hi Lucy,

The thing to remember with integers and strings is that you can only add strings to strings, but not integers to strings.

If you have something that is already a string, like `"I's dotted"`, then there's no need to pass that to the `str()` function, as you don't need to convert it into a string.

If you have a number, like `3`, or a function that returns a number, like `.count()`,  then you should turn it into a string like `str(3)` or `str(message.count('a'))` before adding it to another string.

Hi Rey,

The problem with this:

```py3
rey = print(letters.count(letters))
```

is that you put `print()` in the middle. You can use `print()` to show something on the screen, but it isn't needed if you are assigning a value to a variable.

This:

```py3
rey = letters.count(letters)
```

will store the count in `rey` as a number.

When you print it with a string, you can use:

```py3
print(str(rey) + " i's dotted.")
```

Almost there! You stopped converting to string when you save the value which is half the issue you had, but you're still converting to a string before you ```+``` them together. 

Basically: ```str(1) + str(1) = '11'```, but ```str(1+1) = '2'```.

It's really close but it's putting the t's together not plussing them.
For example:
Line: Talk is cheap. Show me the code.
1 i's dotted.
11 t's crossed.

You use the ```+``` sign to stick bits of a string together. If you miss out a ```+``` sign, python panics because it's looking for either the ```+``` or the ```)``` indicating the end of the ```print``` statement, and when it doesn't find either it doesn't know what to do. 

To convert numbers into a string ```str(a)``` works and ```str(a) + str(b)``` works, but ```str(a)(b)``` doesn't work so b is treated like an integer that hasn't been stuck to anything. 

In your case, I think you want ```str(a+b)``` so you can add the two ```'t'``` counts together, then convert them into a string. To do that you'll have to make sure ```names``` and ```namess``` are saved as numbers (what the ```.count()``` returns) and not converted into strings (like you're doing in this line: ```names = str(msg.count('t'))```).

Hope this helps!

You're not bugging me - I'm here to answer your questions! :)

When you add two strings together, it joins them up, so `"hello" + "world"` becomes `"helloworld"`.

This is the same with any strings, even the ones which we know have numbers in them. The computer still sees strings as words, so `"1" + "1"` would be `"11"`, and `"1" + "2" + "3"` would be `"123"`.

So! You're really, really close. Think carefully about which things you want to add together as numbers, and which things you want to join together as strings.

**Hint** - you're totally allowed to have multiple things inside `str()` brackets. The computer does all the calculations inside the brackets first, and then turns the **result** into a string.

e.g. ```str(1 + 1)``` would give us `"2"` as a string.

`str()` lets the computer know that **anything inside the brackets** should be treated as a string. Just like how `print()` prints everything within the brackets!

Here's an example:
```python3
number = 5
print("My number is " + number)
```
This would give us a type error, because we're trying to add together words and numbers, which is super confusing!

But if we did this:
```python3
number = 5
string_number = str(number)
print("My number is " + string_number)
```
The computer knows now to treat the variable `string_number` as a string, so it can join them together without getting confused.

Hi,

You must think about the difference between numbers and strings.

The ` + ` operator can be used on both. On numbers is adds the two number together. With strings is places one string after the other.

```py3
print (3 + 5)
print ('a' + 'b')
```

The `str()` function turns a number into a string. So:

```py3
print (str(5) + str(6))
```

prints ` 56 `.

Hi Liam - glad you've worked it out! The problem was in ```print(i + "t's crossed.")```. The ```TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for +: 'int' and 'str'```part means that addition can't be done on both strings and integers at the same time - adding 2 and 4 to get 6 makes sense, adding "pyt" and "hon" to get "python" makes sense, but adding 2 and "cat" doesn't make sense. That's why having ```str(i)``` fixes the program - it's now adding two strings, like adding ```"2" and "py"``` to get ```"2py"```.

Here's a hint: If you want to check whether a string `A` is included in a string `B`, you can check that by writing `if A in B:`

Here's an interactive example (you can change the strings and run the program multiple times):
```py3

my_favourite_fruit = "orange"
fruitbowl = "bananas, oranges, and an apple"
if my_favourite_fruit in fruitbowl:
  print("The string '", my_favourite_fruit, "' is included in the string '", fruitbowl, "'.")

```

Your indentation is a bit off. The lines of code that you want to run if your if statement is true are meant to be indented (to show they belong as a part of that if) but the if statement itself shouldn't be indented. Here's an example:

```python
raining = "yes"
if raining == "yes":
  print("Better bring an umbrella")
else:
  print("What a lovely day")
```

Writing a function actually takes away the need for `input()`. You can **call** the function (explained [here](https://groklearning.com/learn/challenge-beginners-2018/w5p1/5/)) with different values.

For the rectangle example, we could write something like this:
```py3
def rectangle_area(length, height):
    return length * height
```
Working out the area of a rectangle uses the same formula every time, so we don't need to care about what the actual length and height numbers are.

We do **use** the length and height in the calculation though, so we stick them in the brackets after `def rectangle_area`. The `return` code there tells the computer what the answer is.

Once we've written the function, we can use it like this:
```py3
answer = rectangle_area(10, 5)
print(answer)
```
This is **calling** the function. You can see why we don't need to use `input()` here - instead, we fill in the length and height numbers inside those brackets.

So this would print out `50`, because it knows to multiply those two numbers in the brackets together!

It will be whatever you tell it to be. At the moment, both of them are storing the answer in `headline`. That is causing the problem. They should store the answer to the `input` in variables with _different_ names (not the same name).

A variable can have any name you wish, such as `headline` or `story`.

Your program is very good for printing out _one_ headline:

```
headline = input('What is your breaking news? ')
print_headline(headline)
```

However, there is a problem if it tries to print two headlines:

```
headline = input('What is your headline? ')
headline = input('What is your breaking news? ')
print_headline(headline)
print_headline(headline)
```

The problem is that the answer to both `input()` questions were stored in the _same variable_. Therefore, we have lost the answer to the first question because it was replaced by the answer to the second question. As a result, the second headline would print twice.

This line:

```
headline = input('What is your headline? ')
```

is asking the user a question. It is storing the answer in the `headline` variable.

Next, this line:

```
headline = input('What is your breaking news? ')
```

is asking the user _another_ question. It is storing the answer in the **same variable** (`headline`). Unfortunately, that means that the previous contents of `headline` has been lost.

Can you figure out a way to ask two questions and keep both answers, then use both of those answers to print the headlines?

Hi Jagan,

This line:

```
def count_vowels(message):
```

means that the function is called `count_vowels` and it will receive input from a variable called `message`. So, whatever message the user wants counted will be provided in the `message` variable.

The error you are receiving is because this line:

```
your_answer=count_vowels.count( 'a', 'e', 'i', 'o', 'u')
```

is telling Python to count the letters in `count_vowels`, which is _not_ a string.

Can you figure out how to change that line to count the right thing?

Also, please note that the `.count()` command can only count _one thing at a time_. So, you might want to start by having it count the number of lowercase A's.

Once you have that working, try to figure out how to count all the vowels. Each vowel will need a separate `.count()` command.

**Tip:** The `.count()` command can only count _one thing at a time_. For example, it can only count one vowel at a time.

Therefore, this:

```
message.count('a', 'e')
```

will not work.

You will need to use multiple `.count()` commands to count all the vowels.

the number of E's is being stored in `count_vowels`, but it is **overwriting** the old value in `count_vowels`. Therefore, the number of A's is lost.

Hi Chard,

This line:

```
def count_vowels(message):
```

means that the function is called `count_vowels` and it will receive input from a variable called `message`. So, whatever message the user wants counted will be provided in the `message` variable.

The error you are receiving is because this line:

```
count_vowels = (count_vowels.count( ...))
```

is telling Python to count the letters in `count_vowels`, which is not a string.

Can you figure out how to change it to count the right thing?

Also, please note that the `.count()` command can only count **one thing at a time**. So, you might want to start by having it count the number of lowercase A's.

Once you have that working, try to figure out how to count all the vowels. Each vowel will need a separate `.count()` command.

You actually pretty much had the code correct before.
A function is a way of avoiding rewriting things. If I told you "Here's a recipe for baking cakes. It works for any number of cakes", I can then tell you "make 2 cakes", then later tell you "make 5 cakes".

Similarly here, I tell you "here's a way to calculate the number of vowels in a message", and you can use it for any message.

The way it works is simple. It takes in some input (the thing inside the brackets on the line with the `def`, runs some python code, and then at the end you write `return <something>`. That thing you return is basically your answer.

The problem with that `return your_answer` line is that you're saying that `your_answer` is what you want to answer with. But you work your answer out later on, so you can't return yet.

It would actually print out 105! Let's go through it!

The first line stores 1 in `my_cool_number`.

`my_cool_number = my_cool_number + 99` **updates** the variable. We tell the computer, "Okay, `my_cool_number` is now *whatever is currently stored there* + 99," so the computer reads it as `1 + 99`.

Then it does the same thing, but adding 5. It takes whatever the current number is (in this case it's 100) and adds 5 to it.

By the time it gets to the `print` part, `my_cool_number` is 105, because we updated it each time!

message = 'hello!'

print(message.count('e'))
```

```py3

print('This is an example of print.')

So you think that my 'stop value should be -1 instead of 0?

Although I noticed you printed the extra '0' manually -- one thing to look out for in future is what arguments the ```range()``` function expects, which looks like

```range(start, stop, step)```

You may have noticed even on forward loops that the last number it reaches is less than the ```stop``` value.  A similar pattern happens when the loop goes backwards.  Basically, the ```range``` function is iterating over a sequence *inclusive* of the ```start``` value but *exclusive* of the ```stop``` value.

Check out [this example loop](<https://groklearning.com/view-submissions/39782332/challenge-beginners-2018/w3p2/6/>), using ```i``` as our looping variable.

Your loop is trying to set 1 as a variable - Python doesn't like using numbers as variables - for a good reason too. If your program worked, it would set 1 = 10, 1=9, 1=8, .... each loop through, which wouldn't make sense mathematically.

So in the loop 
```
for i in range(0,10):
    print(i)
```
```i``` is our variable, and we're doing something to that variable each time in the loop.

Python wants to count from an integer only to another integer only.

Python isn't very clever - it could say to count down from ```"salmon"``` to ```-1```, which wouldn't make sense, or to count from ```"seven"``` to ```-1```, which would make sense to us but not to the computer, or from ```"5"``` to ```-1```, which again, would make sense to us, but not the computer.
Hi Violet - on line two, you're setting ```newnumber``` to be a string. The next line says ```range(newnumber, -1, -1)```, so Python thinks you want to count down in 1s, from a string to an integer.

Hi Harriet!
Here is the code from the "Looping backwards" slide.
```py3
for i in range(5, 0, -1):
  print(i)	
```
There are three things you should notice about this code. Firstly, it has three numbers inside the range brackets, whereas your code currently only has two numbers. The first number inside the range brackets should indicate the number you want to start from. The second number should indicate the number you need to stop at. For example, you don't want to print 0, so you need to stop at zero. The last number will be -1, since you need go backwards by one number each time the program goes through the loop. 

You should also notice how the "print(i)" line in the example has been indented (or spaced further to the right). This is because the "print(i)" line is being executed "inside" the loop. 

Finally, your code does not have a colon after the "for statement". Notice how the example has a colon at the end of  "for i in range(5, 0, -1): ". This is a part of the Python syntax that needs to be in every loop.

If you fix these three simple things, you should be able to pass this problem. 
Good luck!

Hi Steph! You're really close! I think the notes on looping through numbers, starting from [here](https://groklearning.com/learn/challenge-beginners-2018/w3p2/3/) will be really useful for you.

Remember, the way `range(start, stop, step)` works is that it goes through the numbers from `start` to `stop` (*including* `start`, but *excluding* `stop`), while stepping through the numbers `step` at a time.

In your case, you're trying to do `range(0, number, -1)`, which is starting at `0`, and trying to reach `number` by stepping `-1` at a time, which probably won't work since `number` is greater than `0`.

Good luck! :)

Remember that the computer reads each line in the order it's written, so if you want it to print something after the loop, it has to go underneath the loop.

See how the lines in your loop are **indented** (which just means they have a couple of spaces before them)? That's the computer's way of knowing which lines of code belong to the loop.

To take stuff out of the loop, you can delete the spaces in front of the line.

To make `range` work, we need to give it a couple of things, a starting number, a ending number, and a step. It should look like this: 

`range(start, stop, step)`

For example: 
- `range(4, 0, -1)` gives the numbers `4, 3, 2, 1`, 
- `range(0, 10, 2)` gives the numbers `0, 2, 4, 6, 8`.

Yeah, exactly - nice work!! :D

`else` goes at the end of your `if`s and `elif`s. Unlike `if` and `elif`, you don't need to type in something to check after it. You can just write something like:

```python3
else:
    print("Hello!")
```
The computer knows when you write `else` that it's checking for **everything else** other than the things you've told it to check before.
It would print out "I've never heard of that weather!")

Great!

Here's some code that asks someone what the weather is.
```python3
weather = input("What's the weather? ")
if weather == "sunny":
    print("It's sunny!")
elif weather == "rainy":
    print("It's rainy!")
elif weather == "cloudy":
    print("It's cloudy!")
else:
    print("I've never heard of that weather!")
```
Let's say the person types in `"cloudy"`! The computer reads every line in order. It's not sunny, and it's not rainy, so it continues and checks if it's cloudy. Because the person typed in `"cloudy"`, the program prints out `"It's cloudy!"`

But there are **HEAPS** of other things someone could type in. It could be windy, or stormy.

Because "windy" and "stormy" don't match with sunny, or rainy, or cloudy, the computer reads the last line. If the person typed in **anything else** other than those first three words, it will print `"I've never heard of that weather!"`

We can be really silly - let's say someone types in `"dog"`. What would the program print out?

Hi Chloe. It looks like you have quite a tricky problem there.  Unfortunately, computers have multiple ways of representing a space character. It looks like in your `'MAYDAY??MAYDAY!'` message, you've used a different type of space than the normal one you get when you hit the space bar, and the marker is getting confused. This is extra tricky, because it's basically impossible to see the difference with your eyes alone.

Sometimes this can happens if you copy and paste text from somewhere else, such as a different program on your computer. In the future, it's best if you write your code in the Grok website (you can use the save button to make sure you don't lose anything). This will make sure this doesn't happen again.

To answer your question: the `int()` function takes in a string, just like the `print()` function does, and tries to turn it into a whole number (or _integer_)

So `int('5')` returns `5`, but `int('hi')` throws an error!

```py3
print('5' + '3')
x = int('5')
y = int('3')
print(x + y)
```

```py3
x = int('hi')
print(x + 3)
```

Imagine that you had three options to pick from A, B or C. One way to write this is to check if the input is A and then if it is not A, check if it is B and then if it is not B, check if it is C. But you know that it has to be one of these and you want to complain about anything else.

The way to write this is:
```py3
if option == 'A':
  print('It was the first option')
elif option == 'B':
    print('It was the second option')
elif option == 'C':
    print('It was the third option')
else
    print('The option is bad')
```

There are days when you feel like throwing your computer out the window because you can't work something out, but then there are the days when you do something that feels like magic and you can't stop smiling.

Good luck with the rest of the challenge, you are learning lots and there are some great people here and in the GPN to help you.

Hi Reece,

I volunteered to be a tutor because (a) I really like doing the challenge myself and (b) I enjoy working with students and love seeing their reaction when they work on a problem and solve it. I am a high school teacher now and used to be a professional software developer some years ago. It was fantastic and great fun to work on a problem and create a really unique solution to it - and my work took me all around the world too. It was hard at times, but also the right level of challenge because it always meant I was learning.  Right now, I am learning a language called Swift and teaching my students (all girls, by the way!) how to make apps for the Apple environment. Some other students are learning Javascript, and we have another bunch of students solving problems in Python!  Coding teaches you how to be persistent, think about problems in different ways and you get to create something that wasn?€?t there before.

This may sound strange, but I often say to my students that if they find something hard, it?€?s a sign that their brain is reacting to the challenge and actively making new connections. So, congratulations on finding it hard - it shows that you are really applying yourself! It?€?s also what makes programming so satisfying - once you figure it out, the sense of achievement and euphoria is just fabulous! You making it to GPN is a great start - you seem keen to learn, so keep practicing, ask for help and see if you can go along to more of the GPN meets. Good luck with the rest of the challenge. :)

Hi Reese!

It's Renee from this morning! 

Happy to answer some questions for you and there are some other tutors who are going to answer some questions for you in a bit too :D

So to answer your question about how the tutors picked. All the the tutors are volunteers and we basically take who ever would like to volunteer who knows some coding and wants to work with the rest of the tutor team. It's a great way to learn more coding by teaching, so we are really happy to have all the volunteers we can get to help them learn. The volunteers range from university students, to teachers, to professional software developers. 

So I am a professional software developer and I don't know if I would say it is easy. I would say that you are always learning something new. As you find with the NCSS Challenge problems, once you know what you need to do you just need to type it out. It is often not that much code, the typing doesn't take very long. Most of my job as a software developer is thinking, thinking about all the different parts of a problem, thinking about where I need to write the code to add a feature, thinking about all the parts of the system that my code will interact with. Typing the code doesn't take that long once you know what you want to type and where you want to type it. But you often need to learn something new before you actually write the code. So that's what I do every day, lots of thinking and then working out what I need to learn to solve a problem. 

So yes, programming is always a tad challenging for me too! Because you always need to learn something new! But it's normally because you are solving a new and interesting problem every single day, so it is very exciting. And other software developers are normally very happy to help you learn things, so that is pretty fun too :D 

And yes there are lots of female tutors! You'll talk to a couple more in a second :)

Hi Dilraaj!

When an `if` statement ends, the next instruction is run.

So, your program first checks:

```py3
if msg == 'ROGER':
```

If it is `ROGER`, then the message is printed.

The program then continues with the next instruction that is _not indented_, which would be:

```py3
if msg == 'OVER AND OUT':
```

In this case, the message is not `OVER AND OUT`, so the `else` is checked. That's why you are getting two messages.

I suggest you go back one page and look at the example to see how it handled this situation.

Hi Pia,

The ```ValueError: invalid literal for int()``` error message means your program is trying to turn something into a number (an integer) which it doesn't know how to -- in your case it's trying to change the string ```'cheese'``` into a number, which doesn't make sense to the ```int()``` function.

If you look back one slide you'll see that the ```ord()``` function lets you turn a single character into a number (its unicode value).

The challenge for your program is how to do this for every letter in the input string.

These lines:

```py3
for i in code:
 cod = ord(i)
print(cod) 
```

are saying "for each letter in `code`, set `cod = ord(i)`

Only when it has finished every letter, will it `print(cod)`. That is because it looks at the spaces (indents) at the start of each line. Because `print` is all the way on the left, it will only run after the `for` loop is finished.

Put an extra space before `print` and you should see something different.
Try putting the `print` _within_ the `for` loop by indenting it. That way, it will `print` for every value of `i`.

This:

code = ord('i')
```

means "take the ordinal value of the letter `i`"

code = ord(i)

means: "Take the ordinal value of the letter that is stored in the variable called `i`"

You might be wondering why we use 0 to access the first character in the string ?€? why wouldn't we be using a 1?

This is because in programming, and in general in computer science, we start counting from 0 rather than from 1.

So the first character in a string is at index 0, the second character is at index 1, the third character is at index 2, and so on.

First try to print each letter in the word, one by one. If you need a refresher on for loops take a look [here](https://groklearning.com/learn/challenge-beginners-2018/w3p2/1/).

g=input('Pie idea: ')

This line:

```
for code in range (msg):

will return numbers because `range()` generates a sequence of numbers.

Instead, you might want to use:

```
for character in msg:

Hi Bella,

This:

```
msg[0]
```

means "obtain the first character in the `msg` variable". (Python starts with zero when counting positions.)

However, this will _not_ work:

```
msg[0][5][9]
```

(It actually means something else that you will learn later.)

If you want to refer to multiple characters, you will need to reference each character individually, and then figure out how to join them together.

Hi Bella. This problem is a pretty tricky one. Let's break it down. 
1. You need to ask the user for an `input` and store that as a variable
2. You need to find out which characters in that message variable are in positions 1, 6 and 12 (but keep in mind that this code starts counting characters at 0 not 1!)

I'll give you a hint, in case your class has finished, so you've got something to go on when you get back to it.

It looks like you're getting a `SyntaxError` - it says "unexpected EOF while parsing". `EOF` means "End Of File" - that the thing that reads your code got to the end of the file when it didn't expect to. 

That's because you're missing an ending bracket! :) 

Once you've fixed that, you've got another little issue with `upper`. It's not a function as you've got there, unfortunately. It's a bit different:

```py3
word = "blah"
print(word.upper())
```
It's a bit confusing, why that one is _after_ the variable name, rather than having the variable inside the brackets, but you're really close to what you need! :)

The `if` would go just before what you want to print. For example:

```py3
raining = input('Is it raining (yes/no)? ')
if raining == 'yes':
  print('Take an umbrella.')
print('Leave the house.')
```

Notice the `if` line goes before the `print('Take an umbrella')` line, and that print is indented under the `if` so the print is controlled by the `if`.

Hi Grogan! It looks like you're getting an `IndentationError` on Line 2 - Python is confused because you've got an `if` statement ending with a colon `:`, and the line after that should be an indented line telling the program what to do when that `if` statement is true. For example:

```
if condition:
  print("This line is indented!")
```

Have a go at fixing that, and let me know if you need any more help!

Okay, so you're really close!

When you're using `if`, you've got two parts:
1. The **condition** (`if car == 'car':`)
2. The instruction (if the condition is **true**, `print('Shotgun!')`

You need to add some spaces before the instruction. This is called *indentation*, which is explained in [this slide](https://groklearning.com/learn/challenge-beginners-2018/w2p1/1/).

This way, the computer knows which code should only be run when a certain condition is true.

Hi there Vivian.

If we have a close look at your program , can we see anything different with the first line?

```py3
 Transport = input('How will we get there? ')
if Transport == 'car':
  print('Time to go.')
print('Shotgun !')

else:
  print('Time to go.')
```

If you look closely, see how there's a space before the word `Transport`.

Because python is really picky about indentation, that space will cause it to get confused about what you meant.  If you remove the space, the error should go away.

Hi Hayley,

Hi Junaid, I can see you've made a great start on this one! :)

Here's a hint: In an `if` block, you can use `else` to catch all cases that didn't match earlier in the `if` block. Here's an interactive example:

```py3
line = input("What colour? ")
if line == "blue":
  print("I like blue as well.") 
else:
  print("Sorry, but I prefer blue to that colour.")
```

Well, we need to start using a *variable*. Your first line (`question = input('Simon says? ')`) assigns the result of the question to a *variable called `question`*. Hi Jash,

You have the right idea, that's great! Your problem is your variable names. Computers read individual words looking for methods or commands, as soon as it hits a space it thinks it has an instruction to follow. So in your first variable it thinks 'first' is a command it needs to follow, like ```print```. 

You can fix this by leaving out spaces or changing the spaces into underscores (for example 'first_ingredient') or by using one word variable names. 

Good luck!

Nice work!

When you use a `print` statement, it always comes with brackets like this:

`print("Hello, world!")`

And the thing you want to print has to go inside the brackets, even when you're printing multiple things stuck together. For example:

`print("The first thing is " + first + ", and the second thing is " + second)`

Try rewriting your `print` line with brackets, and see what happens!

There's a few problems here, when we have a word for user input. That value is saved in a variable (in this case `name`).

The `for` loop should look something like:

```
for letter in word:
  # do something with each letter
```

Here, the for loop has a variable `letter` that we can use for each letter in the word.

The word is what the user inputs, which is stored in the variable that the user inputs. 

```
word = input('oh hai enter a word here: ')
```

Hi Alexander,

This question is asking you to use a `for` loop to print each letter of *any* word in uppercase.

You're actually really close. Your `for` loop does that. But after that the lines:
```
print(name[C])
```
etc. are going to throw an error. When we access a string, we use an integer, which corresponds to the index. So `print(name[0])` would get the first character.

But in this question, you don't need that. So you can delete all of those lines. 

What you need to do, is convert the letters to uppercase before printing.

Hi Tori,

Good work so far. Looking through your line 3, the syntax looks pretty good but the "for word in word" part is confusing. What you really want it to do is separate the two.

The for .. in command allows you to loop through something and process it one at a time. This might be the letters in a word, or student marks in a test or so on. 
Instead of saying " for word in word", what you really want to do is keep the variable names separate. "word" is what you want in the second part of that command, but the first part can be something that makes more sense - in this case, you can call the variable "letter"

So -

for letter in word:
  print(letter.upper())

This goes through the word, one letter at a time. Inside the loop, it takes the individual letter it is up to, converts it to upper case and then prints it out.

See if you can work through that. Once you get the letters printing out, you need to print out the full word again in capitals at the end.

Hi Bianca,

Your submission is sooo close! Just like Simon Says, variables (in `black`) are different from strings (in `'green'`). For example, the following code would print "name" every time:
```
print('name')
```
But this code would print a different value each time, depending on what was stored inside `name`:
```
print(name)
```

We can add strings and variables together, just being careful to only use quotes for strings and not for variables.

```
'My name is ' + 'name' # Prints "My name is name"
My name is + 'name' # Gives a syntax error
'My name is' + name # Prints "My name is Bianca"
                    # (or whatever the value stored in name is)
```

Does that make sense? I hope this helps! :)

Keep up the good work! :)

Hi Mikaela,

Coding is simply telling the computer what to do in a language it can understand.

I think a good way to understand computer languages is to read them aloud. For example:

```py3
animal = input('Favourite animal? ')
print('I like ' + animal + ' too!')
```
Can be read as: input from the user the answer to the question "Favourite animal". Print the words "I Like " the animal the user types " too!"

The answer to this problem is very similar to my example above, except with a name instead of an animal.

Hi Divyani! Thanks for taking part in the NCSS Challenge. You're doing great so far! :D

Your solution is coming along great, but just as a hint... Think about what the following code would do:

```
print('Divyani')
```
That code would print the name 'Divyani' every time.

Now, what about the following code:

```
name = 'Divyani'
print(name)
```

It does the exact same thing, except now we have a variable called 'name' that we store the value 'Divyani' in and print the value of that.

Now what would happen if we changed the first line to:
```
name = input('What is your name?')
```
Now this is different - when we run the program, each time it runs, it will print something different, depending on what the user typed in.

Hope this helps! :) Keep up the great work! :D

Hi Jay,

If you try to access part of a string that doesn't exist, you will get the **index is out of range** error.

For example, if `a = 'hello`, then trying to access `a[5]` will give an error because that is the 6th position in the string, but there are only 5 characters.

You will need to find a way for your program to work correctly without knowing how big the word will be. If you look back over the last three pages, you should find information that can help you for "slicing" a string.

Nope, it isn't making a decision at all :(

In the earlier exercises, when we used `==` or `>` or `<` those were making decisions, Python was figuring out if what we typed was `True` or `False`.

In this case, the `if statement` is not making a decision, `command.title()` would have to return `True` or `False`. Does that make sense?
is it making a decision on if the command is in title form??

`command.title()` converts the text in the variable `command` into title case.

For example, if `command = 'a long walk'`, `command.title()` will give `'A long walk'`.

Knowing that, what does `if command.title():` do? Is that making a decision?
yep

When we write a program, the programmer (that's you!) uses `if statements` to make decisions. 

To make decisions we have to make the computer decide, using True or False statements.  Does this make sense so far?

When you've got multiple decisions to make about one thing, using ```elif``` is usually the way to go, because it links them all together nicely and means that only one of the options can ever occur.

The problem was that the else only "links" with the if before it, so your program was going to the first if, and having that be true, then going to the second if, and having that be false. Hi Ethan,

You're really close!

Let's look at this line:
```py3
if name == name.islower():
```

`islower()` returns (turns into) `True` or `False`, so you're comparing `name == True` or `name == False` - as per [these notes](https://groklearning.com/learn/challenge-beginners-2018/w3p1/8/), you don't need to check if `islower()` is equal to anything - the `True` or `False` that it returns is alone good enough for the `if` statement.

Also, the `islower()` method checks if *all* the letters are lowercase, are you sure that's what you want to check?

Hope this helps! :)

```

is not doing what you are expecting it to do.

Hi Timothy,

You might want to review:

[Substrings](https://groklearning.com/learn/challenge-beginners-2018/w4p2/1/) 

 [Substring to the end](https://groklearning.com/learn/challenge-beginners-2018/w4p2/2/)
It says the string indices must be integers
Thank you!

At the moment `food2[-1:-3]` tries to get the characters in (default) forwards order (i.e. 1, 2, 3, 4) between -1 and -3, but there aren't any, since `-1 + 1 = 0`. 

If you had `food2[-1:-3:-1]` they would count backwards by ones (i.e. -1, -2, -3), but that's not what you want either.

Remember you don't have to have numbers on both sides of the colon - no number before means it will splice from the start, and no number at the end will spice to the end. For example:

```py3
word = 'word'
print(word[2:])
```
Try changing which side the colon is on!

Hi Louisa,

Recursion is when a function in python calls _itself_. It is sometimes used for different problems, but it needs to know when to stop calling itself. In this case, `food_combo` runs `food_combo`, which runs `food_combo`, which runs `food_combo`, etc. until it does it too many times and python crashes.

Try removing the call to `food_combo` from inside the function. You will still need to write code to calculate the combo and `return` it from the function. :)

Not quite... In a function, you can write the same python code as usual, but the last line in this function should be the `return` statement. An example:

```py3
def test(x):
  a = x + 1
  return a

print(test(5))
```

So this example `test` function adds one to the number given in the arguments (`x`), and saves it to the variable `a`. It then gives back the variable `a` by running `return a`. :)

Hi Louisa, 
Awesome work so far! :D You're really close to solving this question.

Yes, your observation for using the comma is correct. It's similar to the plus sign but will always add a space after which isn't quite what we want.

When you use the plus sign like this
```
print ('You have harvested' + int(kgs) + 1337 + 'kg of lemons in total.')
```

You'll get a `TypeError` and it says `must be str, not int`. It's a bit hard to understand but what it's saying is that we have an `int` in the string we want to print out. Python doesn't like this because it can only print out something if everything inside is a string.

Perhaps there's a way that we can convert the `int` to a string. Maybe looking at the [previous page](https://groklearning.com/learn/challenge-beginners-2018/w2p2/6/) of notes will help. :)

The problem is with this line here 

```
print(str('You have harvested ' + answer + 'kg of lemons in total.'))
```

See how you've wrapped the whole message inside the `str()` function. Well that's not much help to python as the whole thing is already a string. 

Instead, what we need to do, is just wrap the `answer` (which is currently an `int`), with the `str()` function, so that we convert it to a string and can join it to the rest of our message.

Hi Ruby,

This is a really tricky one because Python tells you the error is on the wrong line.

A SyntaxError means that Python didn't understand your program. Syntax is a bit like grammar in English. When I say "let's go to the " your brain knows (and expects) that I'm going to say the name of a place (e.g. "the shops").

Similarly, in Python, when you open a bracket (like `int(` or `input(`), it knows that there's going to be a closing one some time later. At some point, Python is like "wait, what's this `if` thing", which is why the error is on the next line.

There are two ways to use 'print'. You can use commas, like this:
```
print('Hello', 'World')
```
If you do that, Python will insert a space between each string:
```
'Hello World'
```
But if you add the strings instead, like this:
```
print('Hello' + 'World')
```
Python won't add the space:
```
'HelloWorld'
```

Hi Oskar.

You're absolutely correct! The marker does keep changing what it expects. That's because this is a key part of programming. Your answer needs to read in some input from the user, and then use that answer to change what it outputs. 

As such, no matter what number the user enters, your code should print out the same number of yips. 

Currently, your code will always print out 3 yips. But that means your code will only ever work if the user enters the number 3.

This same idea applies to every question, the marker will always try and test your code against different input values, and will expect different output as a result.

It looks like you've skipped over a bunch of questions before this one.  They're meant to be solved in order, so you might find it easier to go back to some of the previous ones and attempt to solve them first.

Hi Justin,

This is a really tricky one because Python tells you the error is on the wrong line.

A SyntaxError means that Python didn't understand your program. Syntax is a bit like grammar in English. When I say "let's go to the " your brain knows (and expects) that I'm going to say the name of a place (e.g. "the shops").

Similarly, in Python, when you open a bracket (like `int(` or `input(`), it knows that there's going to be a closing one some time later. At some point, Python is like "wait, what's this `if` thing", which is why the error is on the next line.

Hi Elise,

The program is generally correct, but there are a couple of issues to fix.

This line:

```
yup = input (int('How many yips?')
```

is a little bit wrong. It needs to be the other way:

```
yup = int(input('How many yips?'))
```

because it first asks a question (`input`), then takes the result of that and converts it to a number (`int`). Oh, and make sure that every bracket that is opened is also closed again, or Python gets confused.

Also: When you put things in `'quotes'`, they are treated as text. So in this line:

```
print ('yup' * 'yip' + 'ah hah!')
```

`'yup'` will be treated as a string, not a variable. I suggest you remove the quotes around `yup`.
